module.name: Controls
module.short: This unit contains basic classes for visual controls.

element.name: mrNone
element.short: mrNone
element.descr: Series of constants to be used as respones in message boxes etc. mrNone=0

element.name: mrOK
element.short: mrOK
element.descr: Series of constants to be used as respones in message boxes etc. mrOK=1

element.name: mrCancel
element.short: mrCancel
element.descr: Series of constants to be used as respones in message boxes etc. mrCancel=2

element.name: mrAbort
element.short: mrAbort
element.descr: Series of constants to be used as respones in message boxes etc. mrAbort=3

element.descr: Series of constants to be used as respones in message boxes etc. mrRetry=4

element.short: mrIgnore
element.descr: Series of constants to be used as respones in message boxes etc. mrIgnore=5

element.name: mrYes
element.short: mrYes
element.descr: Series of constants to be used as respones in message boxes etc. mrYes=6

element.short: mrNo (not the same as mrNone)
element.descr: Series of constants to be used as respones in message boxes etc. mrNo=7

element.descr: Series of constants to be used as respones in message boxes etc. mrLast=mrYesToAll=10

element.name: TCMMouseWheel
element.short: TCMMouseWheel - record holding data about the Mouse Wheel

element.short: TAlign - the available options for aligning a Control

element.name: TMouseButton
element.short: Type defining the three mouse buttons (left, middle, right)

element.name: crHigh
element.short: crHigh - a cursor constant

element.name: crDefault
element.short: crDefault - cursor constant: use default cursor (0)

element.short: crNone - a cursor constant: no cursor (-1)

element.short: crArrow - cursor constant: Arrow cursor (-2)

element.short: cursor constant

element.name: crIBeam
element.short: crIbeam - cursor constant: shows I-beam cursor often used in text editors (-4)

element.name: crSizeNESW
element.short: crSizeNESW - cursor constant: runs diagonally from NorthEast to SouthWest (-6)

element.name: crSizeNS
element.short: crSizeNS - cursor constant: cursur runs from North to South (-7)

element.name: crSizeNWSE
element.short: crNWSE - cursor constant: cursor runs from NorthWest to SouthEast

element.name: crSizeWE
element.short: crSizeWE - cursor constant: runs from West to East (-9)

element.name: crSizeNW
element.short: cursor constant

element.name: crSizeN
element.short: crSizeN - cursor constant: cursor North (-24)

element.name: crSizeNE
element.short: crSizeNW - cursor constant: NorthWest (-23)

element.name: crSizeW
element.short: cursor constant

element.name: crSizeSE
element.short: cursor constant

element.name: crUpArrow
element.short: crUpArrow - cursor constant: cursor is Up-Arrow (-10)

element.name: crHourGlass
element.short: crHourGlass - cursor constant: shows hour-glass (wait while action proceeds) (-11)

element.name: crDrag
element.short: crDrag - cursor constant: shows dragging cursor (-12)

element.name: crNoDrop
element.short: cursor constant

element.name: crVSplit
element.short: cursor constant

element.name: crMultiDrag
element.short: cursor constant

element.name: crHandPoint
element.short: crHandPoint - cursor constant: Pointing Hand (-21)

element.name: TControlStyleType
element.short: TControlStyleType - describes features of the Control

descr.pre: Enumerated type comprising: csAcceptsControls, // can have children in the designer csCaptureMouse, csDesignInteractive, // wants mouse events in design mode csClickEvents, csFramed, csSetCaption, csOpaque, csDoubleClicks,// control understands mouse double clicks csTripleClicks,// control understands mouse triple clicks csQuadClicks, // control understands mouse quad clicks csFixedWidth, csFixedHeight, // control cannot change its height (for example combobox) csNoDesignVisible, csReplicatable, csNoStdEvents, csDisplayDragImage, csReflector, csActionClient, csMenuEvents, csNoFocus, csNeedsBorderPaint, // not implemented csParentBackground, // not implemented csDesignNoSmoothResize, // no WYSIWYG resizing in designer csDesignFixedBounds, // control can not be moved nor resized in designer csHasDefaultAction, // control implements useful ExecuteDefaultAction csHasCancelAction, // control implements useful ExecuteCancelAction csNoDesignSelectable, // control can not be selected at design time csOwnedChildsSelectable // child controls owned by this control are selectable in the designer

element.name: TControlStateType
element.short: TControlStateType - describes possible states (status) of Control

element.name: TControlCanvas
element.short: The base class for the canvas property of several graphic controls, such as TGraphicControl and TCustomControl

element.name: TControlCanvas.Create
element.short: Create this instance of Control Canvas

element.name: TControlCanvas.Destroy
element.short: Destroy this Control Canvas and free its resources

element.name: TControlCanvas.Control
element.short: The Control object for which this is the Canvas
element.descr: Reads or writes a flag to determine the identity of the Control object

element.name: TUTF8KeyPressEvent
element.short: cursor constant

element.name: TDragObject
element.short: The base class for many objects that are designed to be dragged and dropped

element.name: TDragObject.Destroy
element.short: Destroy this instance of TDragObject

element.name: TDragObject.Assign
element.short: Assigns a particular source to this drag object
element.descr: Finds out a lot of information about the source object, such as its operating-system handle, size, position, how much the mouse is allowed to move before the object is moved, and whether the object is to be kept visible during the drag process.

element.name: TDragObject.Assign.Source
element.short: The object, with all its properties, that is to be dragged

element.name: TDragObject.GetName
element.short: Find name of the object for dragging

element.name: TDragObject.GetName.Result
element.short: The object's name returned as a string

element.name: TDragObject.HideDragImage
element.short: Procedure for hiding the drag image during movement

element.name: TDragObject.Instance
element.short: // exist only for compatibility

element.name: TDragObject.Instance.Result
element.short: zero

element.name: TDragObject.ShowDragImage
element.short: Procedure for keeping the image visible during movement

element.name: TDragObject.Cancelling
element.short: Is this drag object being cancelled?
element.descr: Reads or sets flag to determine whether this drag image is being cancelled. Property has a boolean value, true if cancelling

element.name: TDragObject.DragHandle
element.short: Finds Operating-System handle for this object
element.descr: Reads or writes flag for operating-system handle

element.name: TDragObject.DragPos
element.short: Find position for this object
element.descr: Reads or writes flag with position (as X, Y co-ordinates)

element.name: TDragObject.DragTargetPos
element.short: The position of the taget control object to which the currect object is to be dragged
element.descr: Reads or writes flag with position (X, Y co-ordinates) of control object to which the current object is to be dragged

element.name: TDragObject.DragTarget
element.short: The control object to which the current object is to be dragged (target)
element.descr: Reads or writes flag with identity of the target control object to which the currect object is to be dragged

element.name: TDragObject.Dropped
element.short: Has the drag object been dropped yet?
element.descr: Boolean property, true if the object has been dropped; reads or writes a flag with this information

element.name: TBaseDragControlObject
element.short: An ancestor class for many drag control objects

element.name: TBaseDragControlObject.Create
element.short: Creates an instance of this object

element.name: TBaseDragControlObject.Create.AControl
element.short: The control object that is to be dragged
element.descr: Reads or writes flag with identity of object for dragging

element.name: TBaseDragControlObject.Assign
element.short: Assigns source object
element.descr: Overrides definition in parent class

element.name: TBaseDragControlObject.Assign.Source
element.short: The object that is to be dragged

element.name: TBaseDragControlObject.Control
element.short: The identity of the control to be dragged
element.descr: Reads or writes flag with identity of control object

element.name: TDockManager
element.short: A base class for managing the docking process
element.descr:
The declaration contains a number of procedure definitions that are 'virtual' and 'abstract'.
This means that there is no implementation specified:
these essentially represent 'place-holders', and it is the responsibility of the developer of descendant classes
to override these methods and implement them as desired.

element.name: TControlBorderSpacing
element.short: TControlBorderSpacing - the spacing around a Control

descr.code:
{ TControlBorderSpacing defines the spacing around a control.
The spacing around its children and between its children is defined in TWinControl.ChildSizing.
Left, Top, Right, Bottom: integer; minimum space left to the autosized control. For example: Control A lies left of control B. A has borderspacing Right=10 and B has borderspacing Left=5. Then A and B will have a minimum space of 10 between.
Around: integer; same as Left, Top, Right and Bottom all at once. This will be added to the effective Left, Top, Right and Bottom. Example: Left=3 and Around=5 results in a minimum spacing to the left of 8.
InnerBorder: integer; This is added to the preferred size. For example: A buttons widget returns 75x25 on GetPreferredSize. CalculatePreferredSize adds 2 times the InnerBorder to the width and height.
CellAlignHorizontal, CellAlignVertical: TControlCellAlign; Used for example when the Parents.ChildSizing.Layout defines a table layout.
}

element.name: TAnchorSide
element.short: TAnchorSide

descr.pre:
TAnchorSide
Class holding the reference sides of the anchors of a TControl. Every TControl has four AnchorSides: AnchorSide[akLeft], AnchorSide[akRight], AnchorSide[akTop] and AnchorSide[akBottom]. Normally if Anchors contain akLeft, and the Parent is resized, the LCL tries to keep the distance between the left side of the control and the right side of its parent client area. With AnchorSide[akLeft] you can define a different reference side. The kept distance is defined by the BorderSpacing.
Example1: +-----+ +-----+ | B | | C | | | +-----+ +-----+
If you want to have the top of B the same as the top of C use B.AnchorSide[akTop].Side:=asrTop; B.AnchorSide[akTop].Control:=C; If you want to keep a distance of 10 pixels between B and C use B.BorderSpacing.Right:=10; B.AnchorSide[akRight].Side:=asrLeft; B.AnchorSide[akRight].Control:=C;
Do not setup in both directions, because this will create a circle, and circles are not allowed.
Example2: +-------+ +---+ | | | A | | B | +---+ | | +-------+
Centering A relative to B: A.AnchorSide[akTop].Side:=arsCenter; A.AnchorSide[akTop].Control:=B; Or use this. It's equivalent: A.AnchorSide[akBottom].Side:=arsCenter; A.AnchorSide[akBottom].Control:=B;

element.name: TControl
element.short: TControl - the main ancestor class for visual controls.

descr.p: TControl is the main ancestor class for all visual controls.
The definition includes a large number of constants, types and methods that are inherited by derived classes and types.
These include devices for defining and controlling:

ul.li: the state and position of the object (including alignment and anchoring),
the size and type of border,
the way child components should behave,
the actions to be taken in response to various events,
and the way the Control should be drawn.

descr.p: Properties defined here can be overridden by descendant classes.

element.name: TControl.GetText
element.short: Function to get text-string associated with control
element.descr: Uses RealGetText rather than GetTextBuf to avoid unnecessary read-writes to PChar buffers

element.name: TControl.GetText.Result
element.short: The function returns the required text as a string

element.name: TControl.SetText
element.short: Stores text in buffer
element.descr: Uses RealSetText rather than SetTextBuf to avoid unnecessary read-writes to PChar buffer

element.name: TControl.SetText.Value
element.short: The text string to be stored in the buffer

element.name: TControl.DoAutoSize
element.short: DoAutoSize - method for actually performing the AutoSize

descr.p: IMPORTANT: Many Delphi controls override this method and many call this method directly after setting some properties.
During handle creation not all interfaces can create complete Device Contexts which are needed to calculate things like text size.
That's why you should always call AdjustSize instead of DoAutoSize.

element.name: TControl.AutoSizeCanStart
element.short: AutoSizeCanStart - checks whether DoAutoSize is permitted to start

element.name: TControl.CalculatePreferredSize
element.short: CalculatePreferredSize - find default/preferred height and width
element.descr:
CalculatePreferredSize - find default/preferred height and widthprocedure TControl.CalculatePreferredSize (var PreferredWidth, PreferredHeight: integer; WithThemeSpace: Boolean);
Calculates the default/preferred width and height for a control, which is used by the LCL autosizing algorithms as default size. Only positive values are valid. Negative or 0 are treated as undefined and the LCL uses other sizes instead.
TWinControl overrides this and asks the interface for theme dependent values. See TWinControl.CalculatePreferredSize for more information.
WithThemeSpace: If true, adds space for stacking.
For example: TRadioButton has a minimum size. But for stacking multiple TRadioButtons there should be some space around. This space is theme dependent, so the parameter is passes to the widgetset
.

descr.pre: { try to set the automatic changed bounds If the interface does not like our bounds, it sends a message with the real bounds, which invokes the automatic realigning of the control, .. a circle. To break the circle, only bounds that are different from the last try will be sent. }

element.name: TControl.GetChildsRect
element.short: Gets the rectangular coordinates for a child control

element.name: TControl.GetChildsRect.Result
element.short: The function returns the coordinates of the child rectangle

element.name: TControl.GetChildsRect.Scrolled
element.short: True if the rectangle is scrolled

element.name: TControl.AssignTo
element.short: AssignTo - copies some of its properties to another control (Dest)

element.name: TControl.RealGetText
element.short: Function to get a text-string associated with the control
element.descr: This is the function that is actually used by GetTextBuf, and loads a string rather than performing read-write to a PChar buffer

element.name: TControl.RealGetText.Result
element.short: The Function returns the required text as a string

element.name: TControl.RealSetText
element.short: Procedure to store text associated with the control in a string
element.descr: This is the procedure that is actually used by SetTextBuf, and stores text as a string rather than performing read-write to a PChar buffer

element.name: TControl.RealSetText.Value
element.short: The text-string that is to be stored

element.name: TControl.ParentFormHandleInitialized
element.short: ParentFormHandleInitialized - called by ChildHandlesCreated of parent form

descr.p: The form is a real connection to the target screen.
For example, the gtk under X gathers some screen information, but not before form creation.
But this information is needed to create DeviceContexts, which are needed to calculate Text Size and such stuff needed for AutoSizing.
That's why AdjustSize delays AutoSizing till this moment.
Now do the AutoSize.

element.name: TControl.AutoSize
element.short: Whether auto-size is to be used

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
AutoSize permits the size of a control to be adjusted automatically, for example a button can become bigger or smaller to accommodate a longer or shorter caption.
Reads logical (boolean) flag to see whether auto-sizing is to be operated, or writes the flag to say it should be done. Default is false, ie no auto-sizing

element.name: TControl.DragCursor
element.short: DragCursor - the style of cursor to be used during the Drag process

element.name: TControl.DragMode
element.short: DragMode - whether manual or automatic

element.name: TControl.ParentFont
element.short: ParentFont - should the control use the same font as the parent? Default is true

element.name: TControl.ParentColor
element.short: ParentColor - should the control have the same colour as the parent? Default is true

element.name: TControl.ParentShowHint
element.short: ParentShowHint - does the control adopt the same hinting behaviour as its parent? Default is true

element.name: TControl.Text
element.short: Text - the character string in the name or caption of the control

descr.p: Text - the character string in the name or caption of the control

But BEWARE: Text is used in another context in editing controls such as TEdit and TCustomEdit, TLabeledEdit and TCustomLabeledEdit, where it contains the character string that is being edited in the Edit Box.

element.name: TControl.OnConstrainedResize
element.short: Event Handler for constrained resize

descr.p: Event handler needs to be supplied to cover the need to resize a control within the given constraints of maximum and minimum width and height

element.name: TControl.OnContextPopup
element.short: Event handler to supply information when a context-sensitive pop-up menu is required

element.name: TControl.OnDblClick
element.short: Event Handle for mouse double-click

descr.p: Double-clicking is much more common in a Windows environment than in Unix or Linux, where single-clicking is the default method for selecting an object. However, in all environments there could be valid use for a double-click, and a method should be supplied if appropriate.

element.name: TControl.OnTripleClick
element.short: Event handler for mouse triple-click

element.name: TControl.OnQuadClick
element.short: Event handler for quadruple click

element.name: TControl.OnDragDrop
element.short: Event handler for the Drag-Drop manoeuvre

element.name: TControl.OnDragOver
element.short: Event handler for the case when a control is dragged over another control

element.name: TControl.OnEndDock
element.short: Event handler for the end of a docking manoeuvre

element.name: TControl.OnEndDrag
element.short: Event handler for the end of a dragging process

element.name: TControl.OnMouseDown
element.short: Event handler for when a mouse button is pressed down

element.name: TControl.OnMouseMove
element.short: Event handler for mouse movement within the current control

element.name: TControl.OnMouseUp
element.short: Event handler for when the mouse button is released, ie "up"

element.name: TControl.OnMouseEnter
element.short: Event handler for when the mouse enters the area of the current control

element.name: TControl.OnMouseLeave
element.short: Event handler for when the mouse leaves the area of the current control

element.name: TControl.OnStartDock
element.short: Event handler for the start of a docking manoeuvre

element.name: TControl.OnStartDrag
element.short: Event handler for start of dragging process

element.name: TControl.OnEditingDone
element.short: Event handler when editing is done

element.name: TControl.FCompStyle
element.short: FCompStyle - deprecated

element.name: TControl.DragDrop
element.short: DragDrop - Procedure to govern Dragging/Dropping of control

element.name: TControl.DragDrop.Source
element.short: The object to be dragged and dropped

element.name: TControl.DragDrop.X
element.short: The X co-ordinate to which the object is to be dropped (target)

element.name: TControl.DragDrop.Y
element.short: The Y co-ordinate to which the object is to be dropped (target)

element.name: TControl.Dock
element.short: Dock - Procedure governing Docking of Control

descr.p: Dock - Procedure governing Docking of Control

Performs checks that there is already a valid host control to which the present control is to be docked, removes old controls from the list of docked controls and adds the new control to the list, then calls DoDock to perform the actual docking process

element.errors: An exception is raised if there is already a docking process in progress for this control

element.name: TControl.Dock.NewDockSite
element.short: The host control to which which the current control is to be docked

element.name: TControl.Dock.ARect
element.short: The position at which the control is to be docked

element.name: TControl.ManualDock
element.short: ManualDock - permits operator-defined docking

descr.p: Docks this control to DropControl or on NewDockSite.
If DropControl is not nil, ControlSide defines on which side of DropControl this control is docked. (alNone,alClient for stacked in pages). DropControl will become part of a TDockManager.
If DropControl is nil, then DropControl becomes a normal child of NewDockSite and ControlSide is ignored.

element.name: TControl.ManualDock.Result
element.short: The function returns True if a manual dock has been successfully performed

element.name: TControl.ManualDock.NewDockSite
element.short: The new site to which the control is docked, if DropControl has been found to be nil

element.name: TControl.ManualDock.DropControl
element.short: If nil (default) then ignored else used as the control for docking, on side specified by ControlSide

element.name: TControl.ManualDock.ControlSide
element.short: The side on which the control is to be docked, if DropControl is not nil

element.name: TControl.ManualFloat
element.short: ManualFloat - the opposite of ManualDock, allows operator to Float a control

element.name: TControl.ManualFloat.Result
element.short: The function returns True if a manual float has been succesfully performed

element.name: TControl.ManualFloat.TheScreenRect
element.short: The rectangle within which the floating control is located
element.descr:
The rectangle within which the floating control is located
(ie the location of the floating dock site to which the control is docked)

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl
element.short: Remove a previously docked control and put a new control in its place
element.descr:
Checks to see whether there is a previously docked control,
and removes it, then puts the new control in its place

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl.Result
element.short: Returns True if a docked control has been successfully replaced with a new one

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl.Control
element.short: The old control that was previously docked at this site

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl.NewDockSite
element.short: The new site for docking; used if DropControl is nil

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl.DropControl
element.short: The control site to be used for docking, unless it is nil when it is igored. Passed straight through as an argument to ManualDock

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl.ControlSide
element.short: The side to which the new control is to be aligned; passed straight through as an argument to ManualDock

element.name: TControl.Dragging
element.short: Returns True if the control is being dragged

element.name: TControl.Dragging.Result
element.short: Returns True if the control is being dragged

element.name: TControl.AdjustSize
element.short: AdjustSize - Smart way to DoAutoSize

descr.p: TControl.AdjustSize calls DoAutoSize in a smart fashion.
During loading and handle creation the calls are delayed.

This method initially does the same as TWinControl.DoAutoSize. But since DoAutoSize is commonly overriden by descendant components, it is not useful to perform all tests, which can result in too much overhead. To reduce this the LCL calls
AdjustSize instead.

element.name: TControl.AutoSizeDelayed
element.short: Auto-sizing has been delayed until some other process is complete

element.name: TControl.AutoSizeDelayed.Result
element.short: Returns True if auto-sizing has been delayed

element.name: TControl.AnchorToNeighbour
element.short: AnchorToNeighbour - anchoring instructions

element.name: TControl.AnchorToNeighbour.Side
element.short: The side on which we should anchor

element.name: TControl.AnchorToNeighbour.Space
element.short: The size of the space to be left around the control when anchoring

element.name: TControl.AnchorToNeighbour.Sibling
element.short: The sibling control to which we should anchor

element.name: TControl.AnchorParallel
element.short: AnchorParallel - instructions for anchoring beside another control

descr.p: AnchorParallel - instructions for anchoring beside another control
Sibling - another control beside which the current control is to be anchored

element.name: TControl.AnchorParallel.Side
element.short: The side on which we should anchor to the sibling

element.name: TControl.AnchorParallel.Space
element.short: The size of the space to be left around the control when anchoring

element.name: TControl.AnchorParallel.Sibling
element.short: The sibling control to which we should anchor in a parallel manner

element.name: TControl.AnchorHorizontalCenterTo
element.short: AnchorHorizontal - instructions for anchoring

element.name: TControl.AnchorHorizontalCenterTo.Sibling
element.short: Another control to which the current control is to be anchored, centred horizontally

element.name: TControl.AnchorVerticalCenterTo
element.short: AnchorVertical - instructions for anchoring

element.name: TControl.AnchorVerticalCenterTo.Sibling
element.short: Another control to which the current control is to be anchored, centred vertically

element.name: TControl.SetBounds
element.short: Sets the boundaries defining the position of the current control
element.descr: Height, Width, and position of Top Left pixel

element.name: TControl.SetBounds.aLeft
element.short: The X co-ordinate of the top left pixel of the control

element.name: TControl.SetBounds.aTop
element.short: The Y co-ordinate of the top left pixel of the control

element.name: TControl.SetBounds.aWidth
element.short: The width of the control

element.name: TControl.SetBounds.aHeight
element.short: The height of the control

element.name: TControl.SetInitialBounds
element.short: Sets the bounds of the control initially, when it is created
element.descr:
Checks that this is a new control,
then calls SetBounds to set up coordinates defining its position

element.name: TControl.SetInitialBounds.aLeft
element.short: X co-ordinate of top left pixel

element.name: TControl.SetInitialBounds.aTop
element.short: Y co-ordinate of top left pixel

element.name: TControl.SetInitialBounds.aWidth
element.short: Width of control

element.name: TControl.SetInitialBounds.aHeight
element.short: Height of control

element.name: TControl.GetPreferredSize
element.short: Returns default/preferred height and width, to be used in autosizing algorithms

descr.p: GetPreferredSize - find default/preferred height and width

Returns the default/preferred width and height for a control, which is used by the LCL autosizing algorithms as default size. Only positive values are valid. Negative or 0 are treated as undefined and the LCL uses other sizes instead.
WithThemeSpace: If true, adds space for stacking.
For example: TRadioButton has a minimum size. But for stacking multiple TRadioButtons there should be some space around. This space is theme dependent, so the parameter is passes to the widgetset
TWinControl overrides this and asks the interface for theme dependent values. See TWinControl.CalculatePreferredSize for more information.

element.name: TControl.Create
element.short: Create a new Control - Constructor

descr.p: Create a new Control - Constructor. Overrides constructors of ancestor classes and sets a number of defaults. Often overridden by descendant classes.

element.name: TControl.Destroy
element.short: Destroy the Control when you have finished with it

descr.p: Destructor for Control. Detaches control from parents, removes graphics, frees memory and Operating System handles, pointers etc.
Overrides destructors of ancestor classes, and in turn may be overridden by descendant classes.

element.name: TControl.EditingDone
element.short: EditingDone - what to do when you have finished editing
element.descr:
TControl.EditingDone
Called when user has finished editing. This procedure can be used by data links to commit the changes.
For example:
When focus switches to another control (default)
When user selected another item
It's totally up to the control, what events will commit.

element.name: TControl.ExecuteDefaultAction
element.short: What to do when the RETURN button is pressed, signifying default action

element.name: TControl.ExecuteCancelAction
element.short: What to do when ESCAPE is hit (or the CANCEL button is selected) - signifying CANCEL

element.name: TControl.BeginDrag
element.short: BeginDrag - starts the dragging of a control

descr.pre:
{------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Method: TControl.BeginDrag Params: Immediate: Drag behaviour Threshold: distance to move before dragging starts -1 uses the default value of Mouse.DragThreshold Returns: Nothing
Starts the dragging of a control. If the Immediate flag is set, dragging starts immediately. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------}

element.name: TControl.BeginDrag.Immediate
element.short: If True, start drag as soon as cursor starts to move

element.name: TControl.BeginDrag.Threshold
element.short: Least value for movement of cursor before drag starts

element.name: TControl.BeginDrag.Immediate
element.short: If True, start drag as soon as cursor starts to move

element.name: TControl.BringToFront
element.short: Bring the control to the front of the viewed screen

element.name: TControl.ColorIsStored
element.short: Colour is stored

element.name: TControl.ColorIsStored.Result
element.short: Function returns True if colour has been stored

element.name: TControl.HasParent
element.short: This control has a parent

element.name: TControl.HasParent.Result
element.short: Function returns True if there is a parent

element.name: TControl.IsParentOf
element.short: This control is the parent of another control

element.name: TControl.IsParentOf.Result
element.short: Function returns True if this control is a parent, ie there is a child control

element.name: TControl.IsParentOf.AControl
element.short: The control of which this control is a parent (ie the Child control)

element.name: TControl.IsVisible
element.short: The control is visible on the current desktop

element.name: TControl.IsVisible.Result
element.short: Function returns True is control is visible

element.name: TControl.Hide
element.short: Hide this control

element.name: TControl.Refresh
element.short: Refresh the data on this control

element.name: TControl.Repaint
element.short: Repaint the control, ie refill its canvas

element.name: TControl.Invalidate
element.short: Render this control non-valid

element.name: TControl.CheckChildClassAllowed
element.short: Function checks whether a particular child class is allowed

element.name: TControl.CheckChildClassAllowed.Result
element.short: Function returns True if child class has been checked and is allowed

element.name: TControl.CheckChildClassAllowed.ChildClass
element.short: The child class which is being checked to see whether it is allowed

element.name: TControl.CheckChildClassAllowed.ExceptionOnInvalid
element.short: Boolean set to True if a non-valid class is found and an exception has been raised

element.name: TControl.CheckNewParent
element.short: Checks a new parent for this control

element.name: TControl.CheckNewParent.AParent
element.short: The new parent associated with this control

element.name: TControl.SendToBack
element.short: Send to back, ie place this control behind all other controls in the current screen; it will not be visible unless the controls in front are transparent

element.name: TControl.SetTempCursor
element.short: Sets a temporary cursor

element.name: TControl.SetTempCursor.Value
element.short: The temporary cursor which has been set

element.name: TControl.UpdateRolesForForm
element.short: Update the roles for this form; see whether there have been any changes in its role

element.name: TControl.GetTextBuf
element.short: Gets text associated with the control from a buffer

descr.pre: * The VCL implementation relies on the virtual Get/SetTextBuf to * exchange text between widgets and VCL. This means a lot of * (unnecesary) text copies. * The LCL uses strings for exchanging text (more efficient). * To maintain VCL compatibility, the virtual RealGet/SetText is * introduced. These functions interface with the LCLInterface. The * default Get/SetTextbuf implementation calls the RealGet/SetText. * As long as the Get/SetTextBuf isn't overridden Get/SetText * calls RealGet/SetText to avoid PChar copying. * To keep things optimal, LCL implementations should always * override RealGet/SetText. Get/SetTextBuf is only kept for * compatibility.

element.name: TControl.GetTextBuf.Result
element.short: Pointer to the buffer containing the text

element.name: TControl.GetTextBuf.Buffer
element.short: Pointer to the buffer containing the string

element.name: TControl.GetTextBuf.BufSize
element.short: Length of the buffer

element.name: TControl.SetTextBuf
element.short: Stores text associated with the control in a buffer

descr.pre: * The VCL implementation relies on the virtual Get/SetTextBuf to * exchange text between widgets and VCL. This means a lot of * (unnecesary) text copies. * The LCL uses strings for exchanging text (more efficient). * To maintain VCL compatibility, the virtual RealGet/SetText is * introduced. These functions interface with the LCLInterface. The * default Get/SetTextbuf implementation calls the RealGet/SetText. * As long as the Get/SetTextBuf isn't overridden Get/SetText * calls RealGet/SetText to avoid PChar copying. * To keep things optimal, LCL implementations should always * override RealGet/SetText. Get/SetTextBuf is only kept for * compatibility.

element.name: TControl.SetTextBuf.Buffer
element.short: Pointer to the buffer where the text is to be stored

element.name: TControl.ScreenToClient
element.short: Adjust from Screen coodrinates to Client-relative coordinates

element.name: TControl.ClientToScreen
element.short: Convert from Client coordinates to Screen coordinates

element.name: TControl.ScreenToControl
element.short: Adjust from Screen coordinates to Control-relative coordinates

element.name: TControl.ControlToScreen
element.short: Convert from control-relative coordinates to absolute screen coordinates

element.name: TControl.Show
element.short: Makes the control visible.

element.name: TControl.Update
element.short: Perform the Update method specified by the parent control (if there is one)

element.name: TControl.Action
element.short: The action to be associated with this control

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
The (default) action to be associated with this control
Can either read the action already associated with the control (GetAction), or write an action to be associated (SetAction)

element.name: TControl.Align
element.short: Used to align the control in one of four directions.

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Either reads a flag containing alignment instructions (FAlign) or writes alignment instructions (SetAlign)
May have no alignment, may have custom or client alignment, or can be aligned to top, bottom, left or right

element.name: TControl.Anchors
element.short: The set of anchor definitions for this control

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Determines how the control is to be anchored to its client or parent conrol
Either reads a flag containing the set of anchors to be used, or writes a set of anchors. If they have been written, this is indicated in IsAnchorsStored

element.name: TControl.AnchorSide
element.short: Finds which side to use for anchor

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Finds which side is to be used to anchor this control, and what relationships it has to other controls nearby.
For complex relationships, use the Side property of the parent class TAnchorSide, and make a reference eg using asrCenter

element.name: TControl.BorderSpacing
element.short: Determines the border spacing for this control

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Determines the border spacing for this control
Reads flag to find stored spacing values required for the border of the control, or writes the flag to set the spacing.
The properties are defined in the parent class TControlBorderSpacing

element.name: TControl.BoundsRect
element.short: Determines the rectangle bounding this control

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Finds the values for the bounding rectangle, or sets the values.
Bounding rectangle (top-left, bottom-right) is defined in TRect

element.name: TControl.BoundsRectForNewParent
element.short: //**QUESTION - why should we get/set bounds for new parent?
element.descr: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants

element.name: TControl.Caption
element.short: Caption - the text-string appearing on the Control, usually used to identify its function

descr.p: Gets caption as a text-string (GetText), or stores the new caption (SetText). Shows flag if caption is stored (IsCaptionStored).
By default, the Caption appears the same as the control Name in the Object Inspector, and the developer needs to set it explicitly to some new text.
The VCL implementation relies on the virtual Get/SetTextBuf to exchange text between widgets and VCL. This means a lot of (unnecesary) text copies.
The LCL uses strings for exchanging text (more efficient). To maintain VCL compatibility, the virtual RealGet/SetText is introduced. These functions interface with the LCLInterface.
The default Get/SetTextBuf implementation calls the RealGet/SetText. As long as the Get/SetTextBuf isn't overridden Get/SetText calls RealGet/SetText to avoid PChar copying.
To keep things optimal, LCL implementations should always override RealGet/SetText. Get/SetTextBuf is only kept for compatibility.

element.name: TControl.ClientHeight
element.short: ClientHeight - determines the height of the client within which the control exists

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Finds or sets the client height, and sets a flag if it has been stored

element.name: TControl.ClientOrigin
element.short: ClientOrigin - Top left pixel of the client within which the control exists

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Finds origin of client (read-only)

element.name: TControl.ClientRect
element.short: ClientRect - finds the position of the rectangle for the client within which the control exists

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
ClientRect - finds the coordinates of the rectangle for the client within which the control exists (read-only)

element.name: TControl.ClientWidth
element.short: ClientWidth - determines the width of the client within which the control exists

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
ClientWidth - determines the width of the client within which the control exists; reads the width of the client control or sets the value. Sets flag if value is stored

element.name: TControl.Color
element.short: Determine the colour for the current control

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Reads the value for colour, or stores the value, and sets a flag if the colour is stored.
The default colour is the same as the window in which the control is located.

element.name: TControl.Constraints
element.short: Determine Constraints (max and min height and width) for this control

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Determine Constraints (max and min height and width) for this control; reads the size constraints or stores new ones.

element.name: TControl.ControlOrigin
element.short: ControlOrigin - top left pixel of this control

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Reads value for the Origin (top left pixel) of this control. (read-only)

element.name: TControl.ControlState
element.short: ControlState - whether mouse has been clicked, data being read, control being re-drawn, etc

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
ControlState - whether mouse has been clicked, data being read, control being re-drawn, etc. Reads or stores the state of the control.

element.name: TControl.ControlStyle
element.short: ControlStyle - whether the control responds to mouse clicks, can be re-sized, has particular actions, etc

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
ControlStyle - whether the control responds to mouse clicks, can be re-sized, has particular actions, etc. Reads the stored style, or saves the new style

element.name: TControl.Enabled
element.short: Whether the control is Enabled. If not, it usually appears 'greyed-out'

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Whether the control is Enabled. If not, it usually appears 'greyed-out'
Reads a flag to see whether the control is enabled, or stores a new value. If stored, sets a flag to say so.

element.name: TControl.Font
element.short: The Font to be used for text in this control

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Reads a flag to see what font should be used, or sets a flag to store it. If stored, sets a flag to say so
The properties of Font are defined in the parent class TFont

element.name: TControl.IsControl
element.short: Reads or writes a flag to deterine whether this object is actually a control
element.descr:
// standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Reads a logical (boolean) flag or sets it to determine whether this object is a control.

element.name: TControl.MouseEntered
element.short: Reads a flag to determine whether the mouse entered the control
element.descr:
// standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Reads logical (boolean) flag to see whether mouse has entered the control

element.name: TControl.OnChangeBounds
element.short: Event handler for a change in bounds of the control

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Reads or Writes flag if bounds are changed

element.name: TControl.OnClick
element.short: Event Handler for mouse click

descr.p: // standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants

This is often the default action for many controls, and is often the ONLY action specified by the programmer. The action can be spcified by the user, either by typing explicit code into the implementation section for this control, or by selecting an action from a pre-supplied ActionList
Reads or writes a flag if a mouse click is detected, and sets a flag if a value is stored.

element.name: TControl.OnResize
element.short: Event Handler for resize of control
element.descr:
// standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Reads or Writes flag if control is re-sized.

element.name: TControl.OnShowHint
element.short: Event Handler when a hint needs to be shown
element.descr:
// standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Reads or Writes a flag when a hint (a small pop-up box, appearing when the mouse hovers over an object) is to be shown

element.name: TControl.Parent
element.short: Determine what is the parent for this control
element.descr:
// standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Reads or writes a flag to find or store the identity of the parent for this control. The parent is of type TWincontrol

element.name: TControl.PopupMenu
element.short: Gets or writes the pop-up menu associated with this control

element.name: TControl.ShowHint
element.short: Flag to determine: Is hint to be displayed for this control?
element.descr:
// standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Reads flag or writes one to determine if a hint is to be shown when mouse hovers over this control. If value is stored, a storage flag is set. Display of the actual hint is controlled by OnShowHint

element.name: TControl.Visible
element.short: The Visible property represents the ability to see a visual control.

descr.pre: The Visible property represents the ability to see a visual control. If Visible is True the control is shown, otherwise it is hidden. Calling Show sets, among others, Visible to True. Setting Visible to False is equivalent to calling Hide method.
descr.remark: The Visible property does not depend on control's parent visibility. Use IsVisible method to consider this and get real visibility.

element.name: TControl.WindowProc
element.short: Reads or writes a message associated with this window
element.descr:
// standard properties, which should be supported by all descendants
Reads message from flag area, or stores a message

element.name: TControl.Left
element.short: Left - the coordinate of the left edge of the control

element.name: TControl.Height
element.short: Height - the vertical dimension of the control

element.name: TControl.Top
element.short: Top - the coordinates of the top edge of the control

element.name: TControl.Width
element.short: Width - the horizontal dimension of the control

element.name: TControlChildSizing
element.short: How Child controls are to be sized relative to parent

descr.code:
{ TControlChildSizing }
{ LeftRightSpacing, TopBottomSpacing: integer; minimum space between left client border and left most children. For example: ClientLeftRight=5 means child's Left position is at least 5.
HorizontalSpacing, VerticalSpacing: integer; minimum space between each child horizontally }
{ Defines how child controls are resized/aligned.
cesAnchorAligning, cssAnchorAligning Anchors and Align work like Delphi. For example if Anchors property of the control is [akLeft], it means fixed distance between left border of parent's client area. [akRight] means fixed distance between right border of the control and the right border of the parent's client area. When the parent is resized the child is moved to keep the distance. [akLeft,akRight] means fixed distance to left border and fixed distance to right border. When the parent is resized, the controls width is changed (resized) to keep the left and right distance. Same for akTop,akBottom.
Align=alLeft for a control means set Left leftmost, Top topmost and maximize Height. The width is kept, if akRight is not set. If akRight is set in the Anchors property, then the right distance is kept and the control's width is resized. If there several controls with Align=alLeft, they will not overlapp and be put side by side. Same for alRight, alTop, alBottom. (Always expand 3 sides).
Align=alClient. The control will fill the whole remaining space. Setting two children to Align=alClient does only make sense, if you set maximum Constraints.
Order: First all alTop children are resized, then alBottom, then alLeft, then alRight and finally alClient.
cesScaleChilds, cssScaleChilds Scale children, keep space between them fixed. Children are resized to their normal/advised size. If there is some space left in the client area of the parent, then the children are scaled to fill the space. You can set maximum Constraints. Then the other children are scaled more. For example: 3 child controls A, B, C with A.Width=10, B.Width=20 and C.Width=30 (total=60). If the Parent's client area has a ClientWidth of 120, then the children are scaled with Factor 2. If B has a maximum constraint width of 30, then first the children will be scaled with 1.5 (A.Width=15, B.Width=30, C.Width=45). Then A and C (15+45=60 and 30 pixel space left) will be scaled by 1.5 again, to a final result of: A.Width=23, B.Width=30, C.Width=67 (23+30+67=120).
cesHomogenousChildGrowth, cssHomogenousChildDecrease Enlarge children equally. Children are resized to their normal/advised size. If there is some space left in the client area of the parent, then the remaining space is distributed equally to each child. For example: 3 child controls A, B, C with A.Width=10, B.Width=20 and C.Width=30 (total=60). If the Parent's client area has a ClientWidth of 120, then 60/3=20 is added to each Child. If B has a maximum constraint width of 30, then first 10 is added to all childs (A.Width=20, B.Width=30, C.Width=40). Then A and C (20+40=60 and 30 pixel space left) will get 30/2=15 additional, resulting in: A.Width=35, B.Width=30, C.Width=55 (35+30+55=120).
cesHomogenousSpaceGrowth Enlarge space between children equally. Children are resized to their normal/advised size. If there is some space left in the client area of the parent, then the space between the children is expanded. For example: 3 child controls A, B, C with A.Width=10, B.Width=20 and C.Width=30 (total=60). If the Parent's client area has a ClientWidth of 120, then there will be 60/2=30 space between A and B and between B and C. }

element.name: TWinControl
element.short: The base class for all windowed controls
element.descr:
Defines many of the properties inherited by child classes,
particularly those related to size, position, bounds, docking,
the responses to mouse movements and key presses.
Defines procedures and functions related to windowed controls,
some of which override virtual methods defined in ancestor classes.

element.name: TWinControl.BorderWidth
element.short: Property to determine width of the window's border

element.name: TWinControl.BoundsLockCount
element.short: Finds how many of the Bounds are locked
element.descr: // properties which are supported by all descendants

element.name: TWinControl.Brush
element.short: Find which type of brush to use for drawing the control
element.descr: // properties which are supported by all descendants

element.name: TWinControl.CachedClientHeight
element.short: Stored value of client height
element.descr: Read value fom flag

element.name: TWinControl.CachedClientWidth
element.short: Stored value of Client Width
element.descr: Reads value from flag

element.name: TWinControl.ChildSizing
element.short: Definitions of how any child control is to be sized
element.descr:
Reads values from flag or stores values to flag. Most of the properties are inherited from TControlChildSizing,
which you should read to find out more about this control

element.name: TWinControl.ControlCount
element.short: The number of controls associated with this window
element.descr:
// properties which are supported by all descendants
Reads value from flag

element.name: TWinControl.Controls
element.short: Finds which controls are located in this window
element.descr:
// properties which are supported by all descendants
Reads values from a flag; Index is a number signifying which control, from a list

element.name: TWinControl.Controls.Index
element.short: Numerical value to identify the control within the window

element.name: TWinControl.DefWndProc
element.short: The default procedure to be associated with the window
element.descr:
// properties which are supported by all descendants
reads or writes a flag to define what is the default procedure

element.name: TWinControl.DockClientCount
element.short: The number of clients to which this control is docked
element.descr: Reads count from flag

element.name: TWinControl.DockClients
element.short: The dock clients of this window
element.descr: Reads a flag to find the actual dock client controls

element.name: TWinControl.DockClients.Index
element.short: The serial numbers (Index) of the dock clients

element.name: TWinControl.DockManager
element.short: Property that actually controls the docking process
element.descr: Reads or writes a flag. Derived from the parent class TDockManager

element.name: TWinControl.DockSite
element.short: Is this a dock site? Default false
element.descr: Reads or sets a flag to show whether this is a dock site. Default false

element.name: TWinControl.DoubleBuffered
element.short: Are the contents of this window to be double buffered?
element.descr: Reads or writes flag to determine whether double buffering is to be used

element.name: TWinControl.Handle
element.short: Handle for identifying and manipulating this window
element.descr: Reads from or writes handle to flag

element.name: TWinControl.IsResizing
element.short: Is the window being re-sized?
element.descr: Reads or writes flag to indicate re-sizing

element.name: TWinControl.TabOrder
element.short: The place this control occupies in the list of tabs
element.descr: Reads or writes information in flag; default is -1

element.name: TWinControl.TabStop
element.short: Determines if the user can tab to a control.
element.descr: Reads or writes boolean flag; default is False

element.name: TWinControl.OnEnter
element.short: OnEnter - event handler for when the mouse enters the control, and the control receives focus

element.name: TWinControl.OnExit
element.short: OnExit - event handler for when the mouse leaves the control and it loses focus

element.name: TWinControl.OnKeyDown
element.short: OnKeyDown - event handler for instance when key is down while control has focus

descr.p: OnKeyDown - event handler for instance when key is down while control has focus
Differs from OnKeyPress in that the key may have already been down when the control received focus; with OnKeyPress the key needs to become pressed while the control has focus.

element.name: TWinControl.OnKeyPress
element.short: OnKeyPress - event controller for a key being pressed while the control has focus

descr.p: OnKeyPress - event controller for a key being pressed while the control has focus
Differs from OnKeyDown in that the key needs to become pressed while the control has focus; with OnKeyDown the key may have already been down when the control received focus.

element.name: TWinControl.OnKeyUp
element.short: OnKeyUp - event handler for instance when a key is up (not pressed) while the control has focus

descr.p: OnKeyUp - event handler for instance when a key is up (not pressed) while the control has focus
The key may already have been up when the control received focus, or a pressed key may become released during the time the control has focus.

element.name: TWinControl.Create
element.short: Create a new instance of the Window Control

element.name: TWinControl.Destroy
element.short: Destroy this instance of the Window Control, and return the resources used

element.name: TGraphicControl
element.short: TGraphicControl is the base class for all lightweight controls.

descr.p: TGraphicControl supports simple lightweight controls that do not need the ability to accept keyboard input or contain other controls.
Since lightweight controls do not wrap GUI screen objects, they are faster and use fewer resources than controls based on TWinControl.
TGraphicControl provides a Canvas property for access to the control's drawing surface and a virtual Paint method called in response to paint requests received by the parent control.

element.name: TGraphicControl.FCanvas
element.short: A reference to the parent's Canvas.
element.descr: The canvas isn't "owned" by the TGraphicControl, but by its parent.

element.name: TGraphicControl.Paint
element.short: Virtual Paint method called in response to paint requests.
element.descr: Virtual Paint method called in response to paint requests received by the parent control.

element.name: TGraphicControl.Create
element.short: Create a new instance of a Graphic Control

element.name: TGraphicControl.Destroy
element.short: Destroy this instance of a graphic control and return its resources

element.name: TGraphicControl.Canvas
element.short: A clipping window to the parent canvas.

descr.p: The TGraphicsControl.Canvas is a clipping window to the parent canvas.
If you ask for the Canvas.Width or Canvas.Height, you are actually getting the parent control's Canvas dimensions.
To get the dimensions of the TGraphicControl, you must query the ClientRect.

element.name: TGraphicControl.OnPaint
element.short: OnPaint - event handler for request to paint canvas

element.name: TCustomControl
element.short: TCustomControl - a base class for many window controls
element.descr: Contains simple basic definitions to create, destroy and paint window controls and set basic properties like canvas and border

element.name: TCustomControl.PaintWindow
element.short: Paint handler plug-in
element.descr:
This is a plug-in in TWinControl to get the DC,
assign it to our canvas and call the paint method for
descendants to do the actual painting

element.name: TCustomControl.PaintWindow.DC
element.short: The Device Context in which to paint

element.name: TCustomControl.Create
element.short: Create an instance of this control

element.name: TCustomControl.Create.AOwner
element.short: Owner, ie the component that called this control

element.name: TCustomControl.Destroy
element.short: Destroy the control and returns its resources

element.name: TCustomControl.DestroyComponent
element.short: If the custom control has been destroyed, free its handle as well

element.name: TCustomControl.Paint
element.short: The default paint handler for the class
element.descr: If using a control derived from this parent, the developer needs to write a specific paint handler to override this one

element.name: TCustomControl.Canvas
element.short: The area of a control on which its components are drawn or painted
element.descr:
The Canvas is the area of screen on which the various components are drawn.
This inherits its properties from TCanvas,
and that description should be read to understand their definitions more fully.

element.name: TCustomControl.BorderStyle
element.short: The available border styles for this sort of control
element.descr: Only a restricted series of options is available: none or a single border.

element.name: TCustomControl.OnPaint
element.short: Event handler for painting

element.name: TDockZone
element.short: TDockZone is a node in the TDockTree and encapsulates a region into which other zones or a single control are contained.
element.descr: This is an ancestor class for TDockTree, in the sense that it forms the elementary component of which the tree is constructed

element.name: TDockZone.Create
element.short: Create this instance of Dock Zone
element.descr: Specifies the tree to which this zone belongs, and and child zones which it contains

element.name: TDockZone.Create.TheTree
element.short: The dock tree to which this zone belongs

element.name: TDockTree
element.short: A tree of dock zones - every docked window has one tree

descr.pre:
TDockTree - a tree of TDockZones - Every docked window has one tree
This is an abstract class. The real implementation is in ldocktree.pas.
Docking means here: Combining several windows to one. A window can here be a TCustomForm or a floating control (undocked) or a TDockForm. A window can be docked to another to the left, right, top, bottom or "into". The docking source window will be resized, to fit to the docking target window.
Example1: Docking "A" (source window) left to "B" (target window)
+---+ +----+ | A | -> | B | +---+ | | +----+ Result: A new docktree will be created. Height of "A" will be resized to the height of "B". A splitter will be inserted between "A" and "B". And all three are children of the newly created TLazDockForm of the newly created TDockTree.
+------------+ |+---+|+----+| || A ||| B || || ||| || |+---+|+----+| +------------+
If "A" or "B" were floating controls, the floating dock sites are freed. If "A" or "B" were forms, their decorations (title bars and borders) are replaced by docked decorations. If "A" had a TDockTree, it is freed and its child dockzones are merged to the docktree of "B". Analog for docking "C" left to "A":
+------------------+ |+---+|+---+|+----+| || C ||| A ||| B || || ||| ||| || |+---+|+---+|+----+| +------------------+
Example2: Docking A into B +-----+ +---+ | | | A | ---+-> B | +---+ | | +-----+
Result: A new docktree will be created. "A" will be resized to the size of "B". Both will be put into a TLazDockPages control which is the child of the newly created TDockTree.
+-------+ |[B][A] | |+-----+| || || || A || || || |+-----+| +-------+
Every DockZone has siblings and children. Siblings can either be - horizontally (left to right, splitter), - vertically (top to bottom, splitter) - or upon each other (as pages, left to right).
InsertControl - undock control and dock it into the manager. For example dock Form1 left to a Form2: InsertControl(Form1,alLeft,Form2); To dock "into", into a TDockPage, use Align=alNone. PositionDockRect - calculates where a control would be placed, if it would be docked via InsertControl. RemoveControl - removes a control from the dock manager.
GetControlBounds - TODO for Delphi compatibility ResetBounds - TODO for Delphi compatibility SetReplacingControl - TODO for Delphi compatibility PaintSite - TODO for Delphi compatibility

element.name: TDockTree.BeginUpdate
element.short: Update the entries in the tree (increment the update count)

element.name: TDockTree.Create
element.short: Create a new instance of a docking tree

element.name: TDockTree.Create.TheDockSite
element.short: The window control that is to be the site for docking

element.name: TDockTree.Destroy
element.short: Remove this instance of dock tree, and free its resources

element.name: TMouse
element.short: Some properties of the current Mouse
element.descr: Contains information about current mouse position, whether it has captured an object, whether it is dragging the object, and how far the mouse is allowed to move before the captured object is made to move.

element.name: TMouse.Create
element.short: Create an instance of the Mouse object

element.name: TMouse.Destroy
element.short: Destroy this instance of the mouse object
element.descr: Can be a locally defined method to override the method specified by the parent object

element.name: TMouse.Capture
element.short: System handle for the captured object
element.descr: Reads or writes a system variable identifying the captured object

element.name: TMouse.CursorPos
element.short: The screen position of the cursor
element.descr: Reads or writes a variable to determine the position of the cursor (a point with X, Y co-ordinates)

element.name: TMouse.DragImmediate
element.short: Does the object get dragged as soon as the mouse moves?
element.descr: Reads or writes a flag to determine whether to move the object immediately the mouse moves: default is true

element.name: TMouse.DragThreshold
element.short: The least distance the mouse must move before the captured object is moved
element.descr: Reads or writes a flag to deterine the threshold movement (if DragImmediate was false). Default is 5 pixels

element.name: AlignNames
element.short: the strings that appear, eg in the Object Inspector, to describe the possible types of alignments

element.name: FindControl
element.short: Find the Handle for the specified Control

descr.p: FindControl
Returns the TWinControl associated with the Handle.
This is very interface specific. Better use FindOwnerControl.
Handle can also be a child handle, and does not need to be the Handle property of the Result.
IMPORTANT: So, in most cases: Result.Handle <> Handle in the params.

element.name: FindOwnerControl
element.short: Find the Handle for the specified Owner Control

descr.p: FindOwnerControl
Returns the TWinControl owning the Handle. Handle can also be a child handle,
and does not need to be the Handle property of the Result.
IMPORTANT: Therefore, in most cases: parameter Handle <> Result.Handle

element.name: CursorToString
element.short: Returns a string for the name of the cursor as identified by an integer constant
element.descr: Calls CursorToIdent to find correct entry in look-up table

element.name: CursorToString.Result
element.short: Returns a string with the name of the cursor type corresponding to the integer constant

element.name: CursorToIdent
element.short: Uses look-up table to find cursor identifier corresponding to integer cursor constant

element.name: CursorToIdent.Result
element.short: Returns true if a valid entry is found in the look-up table

element.name: AdjustBorderSpace
element.short: Adjust space round border of this control

descr.p: RemainingClientRect: remaining clientrect without CurBorderSpace
CurBorderSpace: current borderspace around RemainingClientRect
Left, Top, Right, Bottom: apply these borderspaces to CurBorderSpace
CurBorderSpace will be set to the maximum of CurBorderSpace and Left, Top, Right, Bottom.
RemainingClientRect will shrink.
RemainingClientRect will not shrink to negative size.

element.name: Register
element.short: Register the components used in the current application, so that they can be recognised
